TITLE: Key inflation indicator up 3.5% year over year in June for fastest gain since 1991
SUMMARY: An inflation indicator that the Fed uses as its key guide rose 3.5% in June, a sharp acceleration that was nonetheless right around expectations.

TITLE: U.S. GDP rose 6.5% last quarter, well below expectations
SUMMARY: While the GDP gain would have been strong prior to the pandemic, it was considerably less than the 8.4% Dow Jones estimate.

TITLE: Pending home sales drop in June — more evidence of a housing turnaround
SUMMARY: After rising in May, signed contracts on existing homes fell in June due to sky-high prices.

TITLE: Fed holds rates near zero, says economy has gotten better even with pandemic worries
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday held its benchmark interest rate near zero and said the economy continues to progress despite concerns over the pandemic spread.

TITLE: Mortgage rates just dropped to a six-month low, and refinances shoot higher
SUMMARY: Applications to refinance a home loan jumped 9% last week from the previous week, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association.

TITLE: The rapid growth the U.S. economy has seen is about to hit a wall
SUMMARY: The U.S. economy is expected to post another roaring growth spurt in the second quarter, before a slow and steady dose of reality starts to sink in.

TITLE: The Fed could sound more worried about the virus and less ready to tighten policy
SUMMARY: When the Fed emerges from its July meeting on Wednesday, it may sound a bit more dovish than expected just a few weeks ago.

TITLE: Home prices broke records in May, according to S&P Case-Shiller
SUMMARY: Home prices were 16.6% higher than in May 2020, the highest reading in the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller report's 30-plus years.

TITLE: IMF warns that inflation could prove to be persistent and central banks may need to act
SUMMARY: For the most part, the Washington-based institution sees these price pressures as transitory. However, it warned that "uncertainty remains high."

TITLE: Housing boom is over as new home sales fall to pandemic low
SUMMARY: After a year of frenzied buying and price gains in the double digits, newly built homes are now out of reach for much of the demand that remains in the market.

TITLE: Yellen urges Congress to raise or suspend the debt limit by Aug. 2
SUMMARY: Treasury Secretary Yellen warned her department will start "extraordinary measures" on Aug. 2 if lawmakers don't raise the debt ceiling.

TITLE: U.S. jobless claims show surprise gain, well above expectations
SUMMARY: Weekly jobless claims totaled 419,000 for the week ended July 17, above the 350,000 estimate.

TITLE: There's growing support within the Fed to announce the tapering of bond purchases in September
SUMMARY: Interviews with officials along with their public comments show growing support for a faster taper timeline than markets had expected a month ago.

TITLE: Consumer sentiment measure falls to pandemic-era low, sees one of largest drops on record
SUMMARY: The University of Michigan consumer sentiment index dropped more than 13% in its preliminary August reading.

TITLE: U.S. jobless claims total 375,000, falling for a third straight week
SUMMARY: Jobless claims numbers have come down sharply since the spring as the economy has recovered, and they have settled near the 400,000 level in recent weeks.

TITLE: Fed should announce bond taper in September, begin it in October, says Dallas Fed President Kaplan
SUMMARY: Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan said that the central bank should begin to taper its monthly purchases of Treasury bonds in October.

TITLE: July consumer prices jump 5.4%, but core inflation rises less than expected
SUMMARY: Prices that Americans pay for everyday goods and services accelerated in July, but about where economists had expected.

TITLE: Job openings surge above 10 million for first time ever, Labor Department says
SUMMARY: The jump came as the quits increased while the layoffs and discharges rate was unchanged, reflecting increased bargaining power for workers.

TITLE: Biden skips victory lap after strong July jobs report, warns of economic peril from rising Covid cases
SUMMARY: President Joe Biden said the strong July jobs numbers were no cause for celebration, because rising Covid cases pose an urgent threat.

TITLE: Here's where the jobs are — in one chart
SUMMARY: The hiring blitz at bars, restaurants and hotels continued in July and led the U.S. to yet another robust month of employment gains.

TITLE: Unemployment rate falls for every group but is higher for Black and Hispanic workers
SUMMARY: Black and Hispanic unemployment dropped in the July jobs report, but the figures are high compared with the jobless rate for whites and Asians.

TITLE: July’s strong jobs report could prepare the Federal Reserve to dial back its bond-buying program
SUMMARY: The latest jobs report from the Labor Department reflects progress, which could put the central bank on track to dial back its bond purchases.

TITLE: Payrolls increase 943,000 in July as unemployment rate slides to 5.4%
SUMMARY: Hiring rose in July at its fastest pace in nearly a year despite fears over the delta variant and as companies struggled with a tight labor supply.

TITLE: Continuing jobless claims hit new pandemic-era low, falling below 3 million
SUMMARY: Initial jobless claims totaled 385,000 for the week ended July 31, meeting estimates.

TITLE: Fed Vice Chair Clarida anticipates rate hikes starting in 2023, sees upside risks to inflation
SUMMARY: Fed Vice Chairman Richard Clarida said the central bank is likely to hit its targets by the end of next year and start raising rates again in 2023.

TITLE: Private companies added 330,000 jobs in July, according to ADP, far short of the 653,000 estimate
SUMMARY: The 330,000 new positions is also a sharp deceleration from June.

TITLE: Yellen says enacting Biden's agenda is key to keeping U.S. the 'world’s pre-eminent economic power'
SUMMARY: Yellen is trying to rally the public behind the bipartisan infrastructure bill and Democrats' even bigger $3.5 trillion spending plan.

TITLE: Biden approval ratings on Covid and economy fall in new CNBC All-America survey
SUMMARY: CNBC's All-America Economic survey showed 48% of American adults approved of the job Biden is doing as president, up a point from the first quarter.

TITLE: Household debt jumps by the most in 14 years to nearly $15 trillion in the second quarter
SUMMARY: Household debt rose by its highest dollar amount in 14 years during the second quarter, thanks mostly to a surge in the housing market.

TITLE: Fed Governor Waller sees reduction in bond purchases possibly starting in October
SUMMARY: The Fed could begin tapering as early as October under a scenario central bank Governor Christopher Waller set out to CNBC.

TITLE: Yellen lends support for effort to remove the debt ceiling altogether
SUMMARY: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said Thursday she would just as soon see the power over debt limits taken away from Congress.

TITLE: Mortgage demand falls as rates rise to highest level since July
SUMMARY: Higher rates caused mortgage demand to drop for refinances and home purchases.

TITLE: Sen. Warren calls Fed Chair Powell a 'dangerous man,' says she will oppose his renomination
SUMMARY: Sen. Elizabeth Warren charged that Fed Chairman Jerome Powell has led an effort to weaken the nation's banking system, and she will oppose his renomination.

TITLE: Watch Powell and Yellen speak live to Senate panel on Covid relief efforts
Fed Chair Powell to warn Congress that inflation pressures could last longer than expected
SUMMARY: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell cautioned Washington legislators that the causes of the recent rise in inflation may last longer than anticipated.

TITLE: Fed officials say they see a pullback in their economic support even with inflation cooling
SUMMARY: At least three Federal Reserve officials said Monday they are ready to pull back on stimulus even though they don't see a threat from inflation.

TITLE: Dallas Fed President Kaplan to retire early on Oct. 8, citing trading disclosure 'distraction'
SUMMARY: Dallas Fed President Kaplan became the second regional central bank leader to resign Monday, saying he was stepping down after a controversy over stock trades.

TITLE: Boston Fed President Rosengren abruptly announces retirement 9 months earlier than planned
SUMMARY: Boston Federal Reserve President Eric Rosengren announced he is stepping down on Thursday, citing health concerns.

TITLE: Costco, Nike and FedEx are warning there's more inflation set to hit consumers as holidays approach
SUMMARY: Shipping bottlenecks that have led to rising freight costs that will be passed onto consumers are cooking up a holiday headache for U.S. retailers.

TITLE: Here’s what changed in the new Fed statement
SUMMARY: This is a comparison of Wednesday's Federal Open Market Committee statement with the one issued after the Fed's previous policymaking meeting on July 28.

TITLE: Federal Reserve holds interest rates steady, says tapering of bond buying coming 'soon'
SUMMARY: The Fed indicated rate hikes could be coming sooner than expected, and it significantly cut it economic outlook for this year.

TITLE: Existing home sales fall 2% as first-time buyers are priced out
SUMMARY: The share of first-time buyers fell to just 29% of all sales, the lowest since January 2019.

TITLE: Jamie Dimon warns it's possible the Fed could be forced into a sharp move next year
SUMMARY: Jamie Dimon said that if the U.S. continues to see inflation running hot over the next few months then the central bank could be forced to act quickly.

TITLE: Stronger mortgage demand points to September surge in home sales
SUMMARY: Mortgage demand rose last week as more buyers came into the housing market.

TITLE: The Fed will try to soothe markets Wednesday, while preparing investors for end to bond buying
SUMMARY: After Monday's market turbulence, the Fed's challenge will be to sound reassuring while acknowledging it is getting ready to move away from its easy policy.

TITLE: After years of being 'squeaky clean,' the Federal Reserve is surrounded by controversy
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve has a big meeting on tap next week, one that will be held under the cloud of an ethical dilemma.

TITLE: Retail sales post surprise gain as consumers show strength despite delta fears
SUMMARY: Economists surveyed by Dow Jones expected retail sales to decline by 0.8% in August and for initial jobless claims to total 320,000.

TITLE: Consumer prices post smaller-than-expected increase in August
SUMMARY: Consumer prices in August rose 5.3% from a year ago and 0.3% from July, the Labor Department reported.

TITLE: Tuesday's CPI report likely to show inflation continuing to run hot, putting the Fed in tough spot
SUMMARY: Tuesday's report of the consumer price index could set the tone for markets ahead of next week's Federal Reserve meeting, particularly if it is hot.

TITLE: Producer inflation accelerated in August, as wholesale prices rose record 8.3% from a year ago
SUMMARY: The producer price index for final demand products was expected to increase 0.6% in August, according to economists surveyed by Dow Jones.

TITLE: Weekly jobless claims post sharp drop to 310,000, another new pandemic low
SUMMARY: Initial filings for unemployment benefits were expected to total 335,000 for the week ended Sept. 4.

TITLE: Businesses are feeling stronger inflation and paying higher wages, Fed's 'Beige Book' says
SUMMARY: Businesses are experiencing escalating inflation that will likely be passed onto consumers, the Fed reported Wednesday.

TITLE: Job openings soar to 10.9 million as companies struggle to fill positions
SUMMARY: Job openings outnumbered the unemployed by more than 2 million in July as companies struggled to fill a record number of vacancies.

TITLE: Companies hired at a brisk pace in September despite fears about Covid and the economy, ADP says
SUMMARY: Private jobs rose by 568,000 for the month, better than the Dow Jones estimate of 425,000 and ahead of the downwardly revised 340,000 in August.

TITLE: As mortgage rates shoot even higher, refinance demand plummets 10%
SUMMARY: A sharp jump in mortgage interest rates over the past few weeks is taking its toll on mortgage demand.

TITLE: Fed’s Evans sees inflation falling below central bank's 2% target after current rise subsides
SUMMARY: The current spate of inflation won't last and ultimately will fall below the Federal Reserve's target, Chicago Fed President Charles Evans said.

TITLE: Yellen sees inflation staying higher for the next several months
SUMMARY: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen cautioned Tuesday that inflationary pressures hitting the U.S. economy could last for a while.

TITLE: U.S. faces a recession if Congress doesn't address the debt limit within 2 weeks, Yellen says
SUMMARY: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen believes the economy would fall into a recession if Congress fails to raise the debt ceiling before a default on the U.S. debt.

TITLE: Stocks are at a 70-year high as a share of household financial wealth
SUMMARY: Equity holdings now make up about half of the $109.2 trillion of financial assets that households own.

TITLE: Key inflation gauge watched by the Federal Reserve hits another 30-year high
SUMMARY: Inflation ran at a fresh 30-year high in August as supply chain disruptions and extraordinarily high demand fueled ongoing price pressures.

TITLE: Home price gains slow down for the first time since May 2020
SUMMARY: Home prices are still higher than a year ago, but the gains are now decelerating for the first time since the pandemic began.

TITLE: November home sales rose due to hot job market and concerns over rising rates next year
SUMMARY: Sales of previously owned homes in November rose 1.9% from October to 6.46 million units, according to the National Association of Realtors' seasonally adjusted count.

TITLE: Mortgage rates fall to a four-week low, but homebuyers still pull back due to record low listings
SUMMARY: Mortgage rates fell to a four-week low, but the tight supply of homes for sale, as well as high prices, caused a drop in loan demand from homebuyers.

TITLE: Goldman cuts GDP forecast after Sen. Manchin says he won't support Biden's 'Build Back Better' plan
SUMMARY: West Virginia Sen. Joe Manchin said on Sunday that he would not support the $1.75 trillion plan.

TITLE: Former U.S. Treasurer on the economy: ‘I’m much more optimistic about 2022’
SUMMARY: Former U.S. Treasurer Rosie Rios says the fundamentals of the U.S. economy look good heading into 2022, even with the uncertainty around the pandemic.

TITLE: Weekly jobless claims total 206,000, higher than expected and above pandemic low
SUMMARY: Initial filings for unemployment insurance totaled 206,000, above the 195,000 Dow Jones estimate and a gain of 18,000 from the previous week.

TITLE: Biden signs debt ceiling increase, preventing first-ever U.S. default
SUMMARY: The debt ceiling increase signed by President Biden is expected to allow the country to pay its bills into 2023.

TITLE: Homebuilder confidence ends the year on a high even as costs rise and labor is in short supply
SUMMARY: Surprisingly strong housing demand, even in the usually slower season for housing, has homebuilders feeling increasingly confident.

TITLE: Mortgage refinances fizzle as interest rates resume their climb
SUMMARY: A mini refinance boom ended quickly after mortgage rates resumed their climb.

TITLE: The Federal Reserve is expected to take a very big step toward a rate hike
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is expected to announce a dramatic policy shift Wednesday that will clear the way for a first interest rate hike next year.

TITLE: Wholesale prices measure rose 9.6% in November from a year ago, the fastest pace on record
SUMMARY: The Labor Department's producer price index was expected to rise 9.2% in November from a year ago, according to FactSet.

TITLE: The Fed will halt asset purchases by March and hike rates in June, CNBC survey predicts
SUMMARY: The Fed will double the pace of the taper to $30 billion at its December meeting.

TITLE: El-Erian says 'transitory' was the 'worst inflation call in the history' of the Fed
SUMMARY: Calling inflation "transitory" was a historically bad move for the Federal Reserve, according to Allianz chief economic advisor Mohamed El-Erian.

TITLE: Inflation surged 6.8% in November, even more than expected, to fastest rate since 1982
SUMMARY: Inflation accelerated at its fastest pace since 1982 in November, the Labor Department said Friday.

TITLE: Inflation is hitting the 3 big areas of household budgets
SUMMARY: Inflation is pushing up costs for housing, transportation and food, the largest expense categories for the average consumer.

TITLE: Investors brace for the highest inflation reading in nearly 40 years
SUMMARY: Wall Street expects the the CPI to reflect a 0.7% gain for the month, which would translate into a 6.7% increase from a year ago

TITLE: Weekly jobless claims fall to 184,000, the lowest level in more than 52 years
SUMMARY: Initial filings for unemployment insurance totaled 184,000 for the week ended Dec. 4, the lowest going back to Sept. 6, 1969.

TITLE: Powell's fourth major shift raises questions about the Fed’s policy credibility
SUMMARY: The Fed is expected to say it will double the pace of its bond purchase taper, while also likely hinting at more aggressive rate hikes in 2022.

TITLE: The 'Great Resignation' slowed down in October, while job openings jumped
SUMMARY: Job quitters declined by 4.7%, falling to 4.16 million from 4.36 million, according to the JOLTS report.

TITLE: Americans plan robust spending this holiday season, but worry about inflation, supply bottlenecks
SUMMARY: But inflation is now the top issue of concern in the country, the CNBC All-America Economic survey shows.

TITLE: Labor productivity rate falls at the fastest pace since 1960
SUMMARY: Labor productivity fell at the fastest rate in more than 60 years in the third quarter, according to a Labor Department report Tuesday.

TITLE: Goldman CEO Solomon sees policy, not the pandemic, as the biggest risk ahead for markets
SUMMARY: Congress and the Fed will have more impact on what happens than the pandemic, Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon said.

TITLE: Job growth disappoints in November, with a gain of just 210,000, despite high hopes
SUMMARY: Nonfarm payrolls were expected to increase by 573,000 in November, according to economists surveyed by Dow Jones.

TITLE: Nearly 1 million more jobs were created this year than the government first estimated
SUMMARY: Labor Department revisions from the first estimate to the third and final release have added nearly 1 million jobs to the initial releases this year.

TITLE: America's chronic labor shortage is 'primary focus' for Northrop Grumman in 2022, CEO says
SUMMARY: Warden's comments come on the heels of a jobs report that shows the U.S. economy created far fewer jobs than expected in November.

TITLE: Hiring was likely strong and employers boosted wages in November, economists say
SUMMARY: Job growth was expected to have been strong in November, and employers continued to boost wages to attract workers in an incredibly tight labor market.

TITLE: Jobless claims less than expected as labor market returns to pre-pandemic self
SUMMARY: Initial claims for unemployment insurance were expected to total 240,000 for the week ended Nov. 27, according to economists surveyed by Dow Jones.

TITLE: CEO survey taken before omicron emergence shows optimism about the economy over the next 6 months
SUMMARY: Strong consumer demand sparked a wave of CEO optimism about the economy over the next six months, the Business Roundtable said.

TITLE: Private payrolls post better-than-expected growth of 534,000 in November, ADP says
SUMMARY: Private payrolls increased by 534,000 for the month, better than the Dow Jones estimate of 506,000 in a labor market that appears to be getting tighter.

TITLE: Mortgage refinance demand plunged 15% last week, but could now reverse
SUMMARY: Mortgage rates rose last week but turned around quickly on news of the omicron variant and comments by the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
